tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving the lift equation and circulation distribution. It requires integrating the circulation distribution to find the total lift, which involves multiple steps and understanding of aerodynamics concepts.

answer_validation.reasoning: Using Kutta–Joukowski, the local lift per unit span is $L'(y)=\rho_\infty V_\infty \Gamma(y)$. Total lift is $L=\int_{-b/2}^{b/2} L'(y)\,dy = \rho_\infty V_\infty \int_{-b/2}^{b/2} \Gamma_0 \sqrt{1-(2y/b)^2}\,dy$. With $b=10\,\text{m}$, $\Gamma_0=20\,\text{m}^2/\text{s}$, $\rho_\infty=1.2\,\text{kg/m}^3$, $V_\infty=100\,\text{m/s}$, the integral evaluates to $\Gamma_0 b \pi/4$. Thus $L = \rho V \Gamma_0 b \pi/4 = 1.2\times100\times20\times10\times\pi/4 \approx 18849\,\text{N} = 18.85\,\text{kN}$. This lies within the official GATE answer range 18.00–19.20 kN, confirming consistency.

step_by_step: Identify that the total lift on a finite wing with known circulation distribution is obtained by integrating the Kutta–Joukowski lift per unit span: $L'(y)=\rho_\infty V_\infty \Gamma(y)$ along the span.
Write the total lift integral: $L = \int_{-b/2}^{b/2} \rho_\infty V_\infty \Gamma_0 \sqrt{1-(2y/b)^2}\,dy = \rho_\infty V_\infty \Gamma_0 \int_{-b/2}^{b/2} \sqrt{1-(2y/b)^2}\,dy$.
Non-dimensionalize the spanwise coordinate with the substitution $z = 2y/b$, so $y = (b/2)z$ and $dy = (b/2)dz$, changing the limits from $y \in [-b/2,b/2]$ to $z \in [-1,1]$.

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{-b/2}^{b/2} \sqrt{1-(2y/b)^2}\,dy = (b/2) \int_{-1}^{1} \sqrt{1-z^2}\,dz$. Recognize $\int_{-1}^{1} \sqrt{1-z^2}\,dz$ as the area of a semicircle of radius 1, equal to $\pi/2$. Hence the integral equals $(b/2)\cdot(\pi/2)=b\pi/4$.
Substitute numerical values into $L = \rho_\infty V_\infty \Gamma_0 (b\pi/4)$: $L = 1.2\times100\times20\times(10\pi/4)$ N.

Compute: $1.2\times100=120$, $120\times20=2400$, $2400\times10=24000$, $24000\times\pi/4 \approx 24000\times0.7854 \approx 18849\,\text{N}$. Convert to kN: $L \approx 18.85\,\text{kN}$ and round to two decimal places.

topic.name: Finite wing theory and lifting-line theory
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 2 Aerodynamics -> Incompressible flow over wings and airfoils -> Finite wing theory

concepts.name: Integration of lift per unit span to get total lift
Change of variables in definite integrals

essential: Understanding of circulation and its relation to lift via Kutta\-Joukowski theorem
Basic concept of finite wings and spanwise lift (circulation) distribution
Definite integration and simple substitutions in integrals
Unit consistency and conversion between N and kN
helpful: Familiarity with elliptic lift distribution properties
Recognizing standard integrals related to circle geometry
Physical meaning of lift per unit span

Main Concept: requires: Kutta\-Joukowski theorem for lift per unit span
requires: Ability to integrate a given circulation distribution over the span
enables: Computation of total lift and lift coefficient for arbitrary wings
enables: Further analysis of induced drag and efficiency for elliptic wings

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling Kutta\-Joukowski relation between circulation and lift per unit span
Needs recognition or quick derivation of the standard semicircle integral
Careful handling of constants and units to avoid arithmetic slips

textbook_references.author: John D. Anderson
textbook_references.section: Elliptic Lift Distribution and Total Lift
textbook_references.text_snippet: The total lift is obtained by integrating the Kutta\-Joukowski expression for lift per unit span, $L' = \rho_\infty V_\infty \Gamma(y)$, over the wingspan. For an elliptic circulation distribution, $\Gamma(y) = \Gamma_0 \sqrt{1-(2y/b)^2}$, this integral can be evaluated analytically.

textbook_references.author: J. D. Anderson
textbook_references.section: Formulas and Equations: Elliptical Circulation Distribution
textbook_references.text_snippet: \"The lift per unit span is given by the Kutta\-Joukowski theorem, $L'(y) = \rho_\infty U_\infty \Gamma(y)$. The total lift coefficient is then $C_L = \frac{2}{U_\infty S} \int_{-b/2}^{b/2} \Gamma(y) dy.\"

video_references.topic_covered: Calculation of total lift from spanwise circulation distribution using Kutta\-Joukowski theorem
Elliptic circulation distribution and its properties

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Use Kutta\-Joukowski for local lift per span \-> integrate elliptic circulation over span \-> evaluate standard semicircle integral \-> substitute numerical values and convert units
key_insights: Recognizing that the given $\Gamma(y)$ is elliptic allows an analytic integral using a standard semicircle area result.
Total lift is simply $\rho V$ times the integral of circulation along the span.
A quick substitution $z=2y/b$ simplifies the integral limits to $[-1,1]$.

formulas_principles.name: Kutta\-Joukowski lift per unit span
formulas_principles.conditions: Steady, incompressible, inviscid flow with well\-defined circulation around each spanwise section
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relation to convert circulation distribution into lift per unit span.

formulas_principles.name: Total lift from spanwise integration
formulas_principles.conditions: Finite wing with known lift per unit span distribution
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to obtain total lift from local lift distribution.

formulas_principles.name: Elliptic circulation distribution
formulas_principles.conditions: Wing with elliptic lift distribution, often associated with elliptic planform and uniform section properties
formulas_principles.relevance: Given in the problem; its integral determines the total circulation and hence lift.

formulas_principles.name: Semicircle area integral
formulas_principles.conditions: Standard definite integral corresponding to area of a semicircle of radius 1
formulas_principles.relevance: Allows quick evaluation of the integral of the elliptic distribution after substitution.

industry_examples: Preliminary wing design for transport aircraft, where elliptic or near\-elliptic lift distributions are used as benchmarks for efficient lift generation.
Validation of CFD or wind tunnel results by comparing computed spanwise circulation distributions with ideal elliptic distributions.
specific_systems: World War II fighters like the Supermarine Spitfire used an elliptic wing planform to approximate an elliptic lift distribution and minimize induced drag.
High\-performance sailplanes often aim for near\-elliptic lift distributions to maximize glide ratio.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate computation of total lift from a given circulation distribution is fundamental for sizing wings, predicting aircraft performance, and ensuring that lift requirements are met with adequate safety margins.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to integrate the circulation over the span and instead directly using $L = \rho V \Gamma_0 b$ or similar without the correct integral factor.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They recall that lift is proportional to circulation and span but overlook the exact shape of the distribution and the need for integration.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always start from $L'(y) = \rho V \Gamma(y)$ and explicitly write the integral $L = \int L'(y) dy$ before simplifying.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an over\- or underestimation of lift by a factor of order unity (e.g., missing the $\pi/4$ factor), giving an answer outside the correct range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrect evaluation of the integral $\int_{-b/2}^{b/2} \sqrt{1-(2y/b)^2} dy$, such as forgetting the substitution factor or misremembering the semicircle area.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Weak familiarity with standard integrals and algebraic manipulation during substitution.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Perform the substitution step carefully: define $z=2y/b$, compute $dy$, change limits, and then recall or re\-derive the semicircle area.
common_mistakes.consequence: Produces a wrong numerical coefficient (e.g., missing the 1/2), shifting the final lift by a noticeable percentage.

common_mistakes.mistake: Unit error when reporting the final answer, such as giving 18849 kN instead of 18.849 kN, or leaving the answer in N when kN is asked.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing in the final step and not checking the requested units.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: At the end, explicitly write the units, convert N to kN by dividing by 1000, and check against the question statement.
common_mistakes.consequence: Numerically off by a factor of 1000, clearly outside the acceptable GATE range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using $b=5$ m instead of $b=10$ m by confusing half\-span with full span in the integral limits.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They see $\pm b/2$ in the formula and mistakenly think $b$ in the problem is half\-span.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Carefully note that $b$ is the full wingspan; the integral limits are $-b/2$ to $b/2$ but $b$ itself is 10 m here.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to a factor of 2 error in the integrated result, giving roughly half the correct lift.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: “Lift is the Line Integral”: L = ∫ (ρ V Γ) dy
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering that total lift from lifting\-line theory is the integral of ρ V Γ over the span.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when setting up problems involving spanwise circulation distributions.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Connecting elliptic circulation distribution integrals to the semicircle area integral $\int_{-1}^{1} \sqrt{1-z^2} dz = \pi/2$.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when you see $\sqrt{1-(2y/b)^2}$ type integrals.

flashcards.front: What is the Kutta\-Joukowski expression for lift per unit span in terms of circulation?
How do you obtain total lift from a known spanwise circulation distribution $\Gamma(y)$?
flashcards.back: Compute $L'(y) = \rho_\infty V_\infty \Gamma(y)$ and integrate along the span: $L = \int_{-b/2}^{b/2} L'(y) dy$.

flashcards.front: Write the elliptic circulation distribution $\Gamma(y)$ for a wing of span b with peak circulation $\Gamma_0$.
What standard integral corresponds to the area of a semicircle of radius 1?
In a GATE problem, the span is given as b = 10 m. What are the correct integration limits for y when using lifting\-line theory?
flashcards.back: Use $y$ from $-b/2$ to $b/2$, i.e., from $-5$ m to $+5$ m. b itself is the full span, not half\-span.

real_world_context.application: Designing efficient wings with near\-elliptic lift distributions to minimize induced drag.
real_world_context.industry_example: The Supermarine Spitfire used an elliptic wing planform to approximate an elliptic lift distribution, improving maneuverability and range during World War II.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect estimation of total lift can lead to under\- or over\-sized wings, affecting performance, fuel burn, and safety margins.

real_world_context.application: Validating aerodynamic models and CFD simulations by integrating computed circulation distributions to obtain total lift.
real_world_context.industry_example: Aircraft manufacturers integrate CFD\-predicted spanwise circulation to cross\-check wind tunnel measurements for new transport aircraft wings.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Discrepancies in lift prediction can delay certification and increase development costs.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Identify it as a direct application of Kutta\-Joukowski and a simple integral. If you remember the semicircle integral or can quickly derive it, this is a fast 2\-mark question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck on the exact integral, estimate that the average value of $\sqrt{1-(2y/b)^2}$ over the span is about $\pi/4 \approx 0.785$ and multiply $\rho V \Gamma_0 b$ by this factor.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 2–3 minutes: 1 minute to set up the integral, 1 minute to evaluate or recall the standard result, and 30 seconds to compute and check units.

search_keywords: Kutta Joukowski theorem lift per unit span
Prandtl lifting line total lift calculation
Anderson Fundamentals of Aerodynamics Chapter 5 finite wings
aspect ratio and elliptic lift distribution

alternative_methods.name: Use lift coefficient expression from circulation integral
alternative_methods.description: Instead of directly computing lift, first compute the integral $I = \int_{-b/2}^{b/2} \Gamma(y) dy$ symbolically to get a general expression for $C_L = \frac{2}{V_\infty S} I$. Then, for a given wing area S, compute $C_L$ and finally $L = \frac{1}{2} \rho V^2 S C_L$. This separates geometry/aerodynamics (through $C_L$) from operating conditions.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Emphasizes the concept of lift coefficient and can be reused for different flight conditions. Cons: Requires wing area S, which is not given here, so for this specific problem it introduces an unnecessary unknown.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when S and AR are known and you want both $C_L$ and L, or when comparing different flight conditions for the same wing.

alternative_methods.name: Numerical integration (discretization of span)
alternative_methods.description: Discretize the span into N segments, compute $\Gamma(y_i)$ at each station, approximate $L'(y_i) = \rho V \Gamma(y_i)$, and sum using a numerical quadrature rule (e.g., trapezoidal or Simpson's rule) to approximate the integral.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Works for arbitrary, non\-analytic circulation distributions and is close to how CFD post\-processing is done. Cons: Overkill for an exam problem with a known analytic integral; more time\-consuming and prone to arithmetic errors by hand.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Appropriate in numerical simulations or programming assignments where $\Gamma(y)$ is known only at discrete points.

connections_to_other_subjects.Mathematics: The integral of $\sqrt{1-z^2}$ connects to geometry (area of a circle) and calculus (standard definite integrals), reinforcing substitution techniques.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Total lift computed here feeds directly into weight balance, climb performance, and maneuvering load calculations in flight mechanics.
connections_to_other_subjects.Structures: The spanwise lift distribution derived from $\Gamma(y)$ is used to compute bending moments and shear forces in wing structural design.
connections_to_other_subjects.Numerical Methods: Approximating the integral of $\Gamma(y)$ numerically relates to quadrature techniques studied in numerical analysis.

deeper_dive_topics: Derivation of Prandtl lifting\-line equation and Fourier series representation of circulation for arbitrary wings
Relationship between elliptic lift distribution and minimum induced drag, including span efficiency factor
Effect of non\-elliptic lift distributions on induced drag and wing design trade\-offs
Extension of lifting\-line theory to swept and tapered wings and comparison with CFD results

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Incompressible flow over wings and airfoils; finite wing theory, lifting-line theory
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question aligns well with the core finite wing theory outcomes, testing direct application of Kutta\-Joukowski and integration of an elliptic circulation distribution.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided detailed content on elliptic circulation distributions, Kutta\-Joukowski based total lift calculation, and finite wing theory directly matching the problem. The formulas for $\Gamma(y)$ and the method to integrate circulation to get total lift were explicitly present, making the solution straightforward to ground in the retrieved material.

future_questions_potential: Given the same elliptic circulation distribution, ask for the wing lift coefficient $C_L$ if the wing area S is specified.
Extend the problem to compute induced drag coefficient $C_{D,i}$ using $C_{D,i} = C_L^2/(\pi AR)$ for an elliptic wing.
Ask students to derive the general expression $L = \rho V \Gamma_0 b \pi/4$ starting from the given $\Gamma(y)$ without numerical substitution.
Modify the circulation distribution to a non\-elliptic form and ask for numerical integration or approximate analytical evaluation of total lift.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text:
The span-wise distribution of circulation over a finite wing of span b = 10 m is
Gamma(y) = Gamma_0 * sqrt(1 - (2y/b)^2)
If Gamma_0 = 20 m²/s and the free stream density and speed are 1.2 kg/m³ and 100 m/s, respectively, the total lift is __________ kN (round off to 2 decimal places).
